title: Something's been bothering me about the Winter's Claw Tribe (food, logistics, and Inuits)
body:
So Sejuani very clearly states 'We do not till earth like the Avarosan', right? That means the Winter's Claw Tribe doesn't farm and it appears to simply recruit warriors from the villages it visits.

They also basically live in an Arctic/Tundra environment.

After doing my best to research, the only northern/arctic culture I've found that subsists on a hunter-gatherer culture are the Inuits who, in their peak, numbered some 100,000 - man, woman, and child. And that's an area basically spanning from Alaska to Greenland. Their numbers have grown thanks to the advent of supplies and prepackaged food, but the current number of hunter-gatherers has dwindled quite a bit.

But the thing is, Inuit-Inuit conflicts are very rare. Partly because of their cultural background which is much more communal oriented but also because they're basically scattered across such a wide area since they can't all hunt in the same area or else they'd over-hunt and starve themselves.

So it's like... Sejuani, _what are you doing_?

I just find it extremely hard to believe Sejuani even knows what she's doing. She has no sustainable supply of food other than raids. Her income and supplies comes from what she seizes. And she has no plan to actually settle down and cultivate a civilization due to her aversion to agriculture. Like, how do the Winter's Claw even survive without agriculture and I guess the short answer is that they don't since Sejuani's the sole sibling to survive into adulthood.

It just seems suicidal. Even if by some miracle she manages to beat out the Avarosan or the Frostguard, Demacia and Noxus will go 'lol, no more food for u' and will steamroll them. 

tl:dr - closest example to Winter's Claw are the Inuits and the Inuits don't have the manpower or food to wage war so why is the Winter's Claw going on this suicidal war?

replies.body:
Interesting!

So, to me, it seems that the Winter's Claw tribe is somewhat parasitic in nature.  We know they do not 'sow seeds and till the earth' and that Sejuani A) compares her tribe to a wolf, and B) she rides a bloody great big boar.  Neither a wolf or a boar is a herbivore in nature, and (while the wolf would prefer meat exclusively) they are both omnivores - they'll eat whatever they can get.

Here's a list of possible food sources that don't stretch the imagination toooooo much, I hope:

* Reindeer/Caribou (or equivalent)
 * Meat (raw, boiled, roasted, smoked, dried, salted, lye-rotted)
 * Partially digested lichen (from reindeer stomachs)
 * Blood (consumed fresh or used in soup, sausage, or a sort of 'tofu')
 * Milk (raw, fermented, cheese, dried, butter, yogurt)
 * Bones (stock, marrow)
* Whale/Seal/Walrus (or equivalent)
 * Meat (as above)
 * Blubber
 * Skin
* Laver/Irish Moss/other seaweeds
* Birds
 * Meat
 * Eggs
 * Bones (stock)
* Fish
 * Meat (as above, also fermented)
 * Bones (stock)
* Polar Bear
 * Meat (as above)

Then, maybe they have herd animals (even if they don't sow seeds) and we can expect there to be lichen (for the reindeer) but any other thin patches of grasses or root vegetables would support these as long as they were highly mobile:

* Goat
 * Meat (as above)
 * Milk (as above)
 * Bones
* Boar
 * Meat
 * Bones

Then lastly the two assumptions are that Sejuani's tribe TAKE what they want from the border villages (much in the way the Wildlings in Game of Thrones do) and then we have the added wildcard of there being legitimate Seers and other magic users who could help identify other food sources and/or mitigate hunger.

_(Standard disclaimer - I'm only as well informed as any player here - I don't have secret Riot narrative team knowledge on this, as I am not part of that team.)_

>Polar Bear

 >   Meat (as above)

{{champion:106}} Ursine disapproves

the {{summoner:31}} .

I know, I know, hang me if you must, but a N*gga gotta eat.

And then they'll have to wrestle when they meet ingame!
Exactly what i was thinking!

Depends on how much meat is actually on a Poro. I mean considering the size of their mouths relative to their bodies there can't be that much on them, and a bunch is probably body fat, although in Freljord the fact they're probably easily lured out, trapped and killed would make it worth while due to how easy they would be to catch and kill, unlike other animals which would likely either be extremely viscous or elusive depending on the animal; you either hunt Boars, wolves, bears and hope you can beat them, or hunt deer, goats, rodents and rely on lying in wait and ambushing/trapping them in a frigid environment.

Would make for a situation where Poros are driven extinction simply due to the scarcity of food, which I suppose would explain why they would be found in abundance in places as remote as the Howling Abyss.

> [{quoted}](name=Sharjo,realm=EUW,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=QW8bwE2g,comment-id=0005000200000000,timestamp=2015-06-22T05:07:52.282+0000)
>
> Depends on how much meat is actually on a Poro. I mean considering the size of their mouths relative to their bodies there can't be that much on them, and a bunch is probably body fat, although in Freljord the fact they're probably easily lured out, trapped and killed would make it worth while due to how easy they would be to catch and kill, unlike other animals which would likely either be extremely viscous or elusive depending on the animal; you either hunt Boars, wolves, bears and hope you can beat them, or hunt deer, goats, rodents and rely on lying in wait and ambushing/trapping them in a frigid environment.
> 
> Would make for a situation where Poros are driven extinction simply due to the scarcity of food, which I suppose would explain why they would be found in abundance in places as remote as the Howling Abyss.

Well, we've seen what happens to a poro if you feed it poro snax - it gets much bigger than it should realistically (conservation of mass, and all that) and then when it has consumed ten snax, it demonstrates a particularly unusual reproductive process and explodes into 8 small-sized poros.  Now, the 9-snax poro looks to be almost half as big as Sejuani's giant boar, which I imagine makes for some good eatin' - especially if to get it to that size, all you need to do are feed it 9 Avarosan game hen meat biscuits.

And then, of course, there's the poro King...
In many ways Poros don't seem...natural. What are the chances of them being malevolent, otherworldly creatures in disguise? 50/50?

> [{quoted}](name=Solideus,realm=EUNE,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=QW8bwE2g,comment-id=000500020000000000000000,timestamp=2015-06-22T15:38:56.822+0000)
>
> In many ways Poros don't seem...natural. What are the chances of them being malevolent, otherworldly creatures in disguise? 50/50?

What does that make Braum?
Secretly evil Poros are funny, but secretly evil Braum makes me uncomfortable.

The heart is the strongest muscle!

( **TIME TO HARVEST THEM FOR MY EXPERIMENTS MUAHAHAHA** )
Someone is watching too much Star Trek :/
Freljord=Star Trek..? Makes sense if you really think about it. Federation, Klingons, Borg; it's all in there.

Big problem though, aren't Poro-snax Avarosan made? They're gonna have to pillage Avarosan just to fatten up the Poros, and then what would be the point with the Poros if you pillaged anyway?! I suppose they could just steal a recipe or something but the point still stands!

> [{quoted}](name=Sharjo,realm=EUW,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=QW8bwE2g,comment-id=000500020000000000000001,timestamp=2015-06-22T16:07:57.783+0000)
>
> Big problem though, aren't Poro-snax Avarosan made? They're gonna have to pillage Avarosan just to fatten up the Poros, and then what would be the point with the Poros if you pillaged anyway?! I suppose they could just steal a recipe or something but the point still stands!

No I think you're absolutely right.  

But imagine you're a bloodthirsty Winter's Claw raider, and you want the best way of storing and transporting food for your high-energy nomadic lifestyle.  I'm suggesting that if you raid an Avarosan village or 12, you can butcher their hens and turn them into easy to transport poro snax.  Then, in the bitter North, as long as you keep 1 healthy poro alive with you, then with 10+ snax you can replicate those poros into fresh meat.

Both grim as hell, and cute as bunnies.
I'm pretty sure that reindeer jerky from Finland is what inspired the name for them actually, so they're definitely not off the dinner table despite their cute cuddly appearance.

> [{quoted}](name=junglerboy16,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=QW8bwE2g,comment-id=0005000200000002,timestamp=2015-06-22T15:14:14.947+0000)

Those look interesting!  Tell me, do they have sugar/sweetener in them like most jerky, or do they use a different preservation method (like South African biltong)?
Sorry to say but I haven't the foggiest idea.

I request an epic cook-off TV series following [Braum](http://apollo-eu-uploads.s3.amazonaws.com/1425422409211/masterchefbraum.jpg) and Tahm, with the fate of the poros in the audience hanging in the balance.  Will Braum's scrumptious savories save the day?  Will Tahm Kench's despicably delicious dishes doom them all?  Tune in to find out!
Only if Master Chef Pantheon is the judge{{champion:80}}

Request to change my name to Nostradamus please.




(Just kidding I think I'll stick with this one)

I should also mention that the tundra isn't really fertile ground to grow crops, so the land that Sejuani must live in was probably not great for agriculture to begin with. From her point of view, it must be that if they can't grow food, no one else should or that their way of life has made them strong. And I say they can't grow food as I've lived in the North most of my life (Inuvik has marshes and permafrost, while Yellowknife is simply too rocky to grow anything sustainable). With that in mind, it could be quite possible that Sejuani wants to rule the Freljord so that they can obtain more fertile lands and that accepting help from another tribe would be seen as a weakness (remember, they pride themselves on strength).
what about yeti {{champion:20}}

One thing that strikes me is Exact Words (tm):

The _Winter's Claw_ do not till the earth.  Other tribes do.  If you (Sejuani) capture a village of another tribe, then they're obviously weak, unfit as warriors, yada yada.  So it's fine for them to till the earth while the Winter's Claw does the fighting.  As a result, she might have a sort-of-serf population of captured tribes or villages who do the farming for her to free up the real warriors to go ride boars or arm wrestle or whatnot.
Or even straight-up slavery.

I doubt that sejuani is really eager to make her tribe big,I think she values quality over quantity.

Scarce food resources means that only the stronger ones survive.If you want to live,then help in the upcoming raid and steal their stuff,hunt some animals or search for edible plants.

If you can't survive in the cold then you aren't worthy of surviving at all.

It just sounds like a terrible way to lose a war. I think Sejuani can't even field the proper numbers to contest the Avarosan. I'm not sure what's the population size is, but the Winter's Claw tribe doesn't seem capable of feeding or clothing a population, much less a dedicated army on the warpath.

Massive attrition rates, and the Avarosan possess more farmland and a larger population pool. Given that the Avarosan are also probably the most industrialized tribe, they could begin building fortifications or even invite Demacian/Noxian trainers to professionalize their army.

The thing is:
what use are these farmlands if their defenses are so meager that they are easily overrun by sejuani anyway?
Ashes problem is that her tribe is so big its hard to defend against enemies.Her armies are relatively small in comparison to her overall population and not everyone among the avarosans is happy with ashe as their leader.

keep in mind that the winters claw is living in the coldest region of the freljord,I doubt they even could cultivate the land.

I doubt Sejuanis tribe alone could rival the city states in power,it is most likely much smaller,but the same goes for her opponents too.

Well, there are also the Vikings...they were nomadic, Arctic-area-dwellers who subsisted on pillaging, and they did quite nicely. And on a side note, the word Freljord (I can't italicize on my phone) sounds more Scandinavian that Inuit. There's a bit of a dichotomy between the cultural inspiration for different Freljord champs. For example, Nunu is more Inuit, whereas Olaf is, of course a Viking.

Vikings weren't nomadic.
They were pillagers, yes, but they had permanent settlements and cultivated land.
You also forget the fact Vikings were seasoned merchants.

Winter Claw's Tribe is more like a band of outlaws hiding in the woods than anything really.

Except Vikings actually operated out of permanent villages that did farming, herding, and fishing. Vikings pillaged mainly to supplement their income and gains instead of it being their exclusive form of income.
remember that this is riot writing lore

One thing you gotta keep in mind is that this is a fantasy setting.

Meaning they could easily have extremely big fantasy monster to eat up there, plants that grow well in the frozen wastes, magic n shit, etc.

It's a bit hard to compare it to the real world.  Especially the Inuit/Inuit conflict, Sejuani is warring with Ahse/Lissandra because they have different values, different cultures, they are Inuits.

And from my understanding, Sejuani is much more based on Norse culture than Inuit culture.

>One thing you gotta keep in mind is that this is a fantasy setting.

So to me unless otherwise noted, their world operates on the same principles as ours. I am not going to make baseless assumptions about their flora and fauna and hand-wave stuff as 'magicccc' unless the text explicitly states so.

> I am not going to make baseless assumptions about their flora and fauna

The person you're nitpicking in the first place rides an enormous boar, presumably coming from up north where she lives, which would provide food for 10 grown warriors.

And Poros also live north, and in great quantities if the Howling Abyss is any indicator.  

Sejuani has the ability to make someone icy and then detonate the ice, if that isn't magic I don't know what is.

Trolls live up north as well, very many trolls that live in large tribes.  They need to eat as well, I would assume they are omnivorous because they do have tusks, which many herbivores have but seem very aggressive and barbaric like a carnivore.  That would imply that large or plentiful game exists in the tundra as well as edible plants.

You know, it's not my fault you don't try to examine every little detail for clues on how they lived.

Saying 'because it's magicccc!' is about as useful to me as saying 'it's a miracle!' for every natural phenomenon observed. 

I see those things, yes. There could be magic, yes.

But barring the possibility of magic, how could Sejuani's tribe possibly survive and wage a war in such a landscape? Hell, are we even sure what the Winter's Claw landscape looks like? I always assumed it was arctic tundra.

But I must strongly disagree. I don't think it's examining much at all if you simply narrow yourself to an excuse like magic.
...Did you read the post?  I only mentioned that Sejuani can likely use magic, nothing more.  EVERYTHING ELSE was quite likely and simply the product of the natural fantasy world.
I think a viable food source could come from frost wyrms. their supposed to be large, and in areas her tribe has access to. they also are confirmed to exist lore wise.

There are also North-East Siberian natives who at least partially subsist as hunter gatherers.  If I recall properly (I read about this a long time ago), some of them herd wild reindeer, but the herds are treated as more of a natural resource to be tracked and protected rather than a case of developed animal husbandry.  From what I know about them, they do occasionally have inter-tribal skirmishes but never on a very large scale due to small population sizes and isolation even between their own tribes.  

Ah, found a Wikipedia page on one (Evenks) of the North-East Siberian native groups:
"Traditionally they were a mixture of pastoralists and hunter-gatherers—they relied on their domesticated reindeer for milk and transport and hunted other large game for meat (Vasilevich, 620-1)."

"The traditional Evenki economy was a mix of pastoralism (of horses or reindeer), fishing, and hunting. The Evenki who lived near the Okhotsk Sea hunted seal, but for most of the taiga-dwellers, elk, wild reindeer, and fowl were the most important game animals. Other animals included “roe deer, bear, wolverine, lynx, wolf, Siberian marmot, fox, and sable” (Vasilevich, 626). Trapping did not become important until the imposition of the fur tax by the tsarist government."

I don't see any references to their warfare, but I recall seeing a picture of their battle equipment a while back - which was composed of mostly padded clothing and a large triangular wooden/leather "shield" piece across the shoulders.
Sejuani is just a crappy leader with no plans for the future. She is going to end up starving to death before the war is over.
Also, instead of Vikings, Mongols had a similar lifestyle. Completely nomadic, pillaging and conquering from their mounts.
